source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_012_chunk4
evidence_span: Nodular corrosion is a type of localized oxidation appearing on the Zircaloys under BWR conditions (that is, high oxygen). The nodules are typically 0.5 to $1 \ \mathrm { m m }$ wide. They can spread, however, and coalesce to cover rather large areas. The attack can be up to 150 to $2 0 0 \ \mu \mathrm { { m } }$ deep [8].

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_012_chunk4
evidence_span: The attack can be up to 150 to $2 0 0 \ \mu \mathrm { { m } }$ deep [8].

evidence_span: The corrosion results were typical for reduced conditions with low weight gain and high deuterium/hydrogen absorption

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_012_chunk7
evidence_span: Corrosion of specimens and loop walls has apparently led to an overpressure of deuterium

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_012_chunk7
evidence_span: stress corrosion cracking due to pellet-clad interaction
